repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.unittitle: Democratic Rural Conference of New York State Records
did.abstract: This collection documents the day-to-day activities of the early years of the Democratic Rural Conference of New York.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: The colleciton contains administrative files including minutes and notes, convention and mini-convention materials, member lists, and resolutions; publications; clippings; correspondence; and background on the history of the organization.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is restricted because it is unprocessed. Portions of the collection may contain recent administrative records and/or personally identifiable information. Please contact an archivist for more information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Mike Schell, founding chair, donated all items in this collection to the M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives in August 2025.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Democractic Rural Conference of New York State Records, 1996-2017. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the DRC Records).

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection is currently unprocessed and is not yet arranged. Individual items may be difficult to find.

bioghist.head: Organizational History
bioghist.p: The Democratic Rural Conference (DRC) of New York State was formally established in September 1996 with 44 members from 27 counties although the idea of the DRC had percolated for many years prior. The DRC sought greater rural representation in the statewide party, a more formalized structure to understand and share voter concerns in small counties with statewide leaders and candidates, and to carry the Democratic message with New Yorkers in small towns and villages.

Today, the DRC continues to strengthen the Democratic Party and promote the interests of and address the concerns of rural New Yorkers within the party and in statewide government. The DRC represents the 47 counties with populations under 250,000. Democratic Party County Chairs and State Committee Members from those counties are voting members.
